books.title: Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone
books.author: J. K. Rowling.
books.description: Rescued from the outrageous neglect of his aunt and uncle, a young boy with a great destiny proves his worth while attending Hogwarts School for Wizards and Witches

books.title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets
books.author: J. K. Rowling
books.description:
The Dursleys were so mean and hideous that summer that all Harry Potter wanted was to get back to the Hogwarts School for Witchcraft and Wizardry. But just as he's packing his bags, Harry receives a warning from a strange, impish creature named Dobby who says that if Harry Potter returns to Hogwarts, disaster will strike

And strike it does. For in Harry's second year at Hogwarts, fresh torments and horrors arise, including an outrageously stuck-up new professor, Gilderoy Lockhart, a spirit named Moaning Myrtle who haunts the girls' bathroom, and the unwanted attentions of Ron Weasley's younger sister, Ginny.

But each of these seem minor annoyances when the real trouble begins, and someone -- or something -- starts turning Hogwarts students to stone. Could it be Draco Malfoy, a more poisonous rival than ever? Could it possibly be Hagrid, whose mysterious past is finally told? Or could it be the one everyone at Hogwarts most suspects . . . Harry Potter himself?
(Front flap)

books.title: Alexander and the terrible, horrible, no good, very bad day
books.author: Judith Viorst ; illustrated by Ray Cruz.
books.description: On a day when everything goes wrong for him, Alexander is consoled by the thought that other people have bad days too.

books.title: Frindle
books.publisher: Simon & Schuster Books for Young Readers
books.author: Andrew Clements ; pictures by Brian Selznick.
books.description: When he decides to turn his fifth grade teacher's love of the dictionary around on her, clever Nick Allen invents a new word and begins a chain of events that quickly moves beyond his control.

books.title: Gregor the Overlander
books.author: Suzanne Collins.
books.description: When eleven-year-old Gregor and his two-year-old sister are pulled into a strange underground world, they trigger an epic battle involving men, bats, rats, cockroaches, and spiders while on a quest foretold by ancient prophecy.

books.author: Herman Wouk
books.title: This is my God
books.description: From Wikipedia: This is My God is a non-fiction book by Herman Wouk, first published in 1959. The book summarizes many key aspects of Judaism and is intended for both Jewish and non-Jewish audiences. The author, who served in the United States Navy and was a Pulitzer Prize-winning novelist, writes from a Modern Orthodox perspective.

staff.name: Naftali Kulik
staff.title: Chief Book Wyrm
staff.bio: Naftali has been an enthusiastic Book Wyrm his entire life. He has read a wide variety of books covering many different genres, but sci-fi/fantasy has always been his first choice. At one point he had aspirations of perhaps becoming a writer himself one day and in the past has resolved to try his hand at writing when he has some time, which is to say, never. His current pursuit of a career in software engineering has effectively put the nail in the proverbial coffin of that particular endeavor. Don't tell him we said this, but we at Book Wyrms think he's probably a better developer than writer anyway, so it's all for the best as they say.

staffReview: Today's featured book was written by Herman Wouk, a successful novelist who also happened to be an Orthodox Jew. As he writes in the prologue, the inspiration for the book came when an irreligious friend of his asked if he could recommend a book about Hanukkah. This revived a dream of his to write, in his own words, “an account of the Jewish faith”, and he set out to do just that.

We at Book Wyrms have noticed something when it comes to books about religion. In general, the book is written with an agenda, either for or against a specific religion, or religion in general. Such debates have raged for all of living memory and will continue to rage until God Himself settles them. This book is not like that. Wouk is not trying to prove anything to you. His aim is not to proselytize or to try selling his religion to a skeptic. The tone of the book is very clear: “This is what I believe in, take it or leave it, I don't really care what you think”.

So what is the point of the book? Jews as a people are relatively well-known in the Western world, their religious practices and what they mean, less so. People who interact with religious Jews on a daily basis often know next to nothing about their religious life, and many Jews themselves are ignorant, willfully or otherwise, about their own religion. This book was written to explain to anyone who may be curious: “This is what we do, and this is why we do it”. Curious about the Sabbath? This book has a chapter about it. Want to know why your Jewish neighbor is heading out in the morning struggling to balance a long palm branch, a small box, and a velvet bag (and in the case of one particular Book Wyrm, a coffee)? One of the chapters on Holidays might help (maybe not with the coffee, but that needs no explaining!).

This is my God is written extremely well, with a light and easy-to-read tone. We at Book Wyrms believe that anyone can enjoy it, whether you are a lifelong practicing Orthodox Jew or someone whose entire knowledge of Judaism starts and ends with bagels (which don't actually have anything to do with Judaism by the way). We strongly encourage anyone who is curious about the Jewish faith to give it a try, and maybe the next time your Jewish co-worker goes AWOL for about half of October you won't just roll your eyes (as much).
